titleInfo.title: State Colored Normal School's new Laboratory School, 1930

mods.note: Student-teachers and pupils outside the newly-built laboratory school. Trigg Elementary School. The structure was demolished in 1988.

titleInfo.title: Dr. Herman Cooke Presides over State Teachers College Biology Lab

mods.note: Professor Herman G. Cooke not only served the institution as a professor of biology but he was the guardian angel of hundreds of student athlete who found paid work in his lab and benefitted from his academic oversight in their studies. Cooke frequently went on the road with athletic teams to assist the managers as well as ensure that homework assignments were completed.

titleInfo.title: North Carolina-issued Confederate Currency, One Dollar

mods.note: North Carolina-issued Confederate currency, $1 No. 3207. Obverse text reads, in part, "The STATE of NORTH CAROLINA/Will pay ONE DOLLAR to Bearer/at the Treasury on or before 1st Jan. 1866." Signed by C. Dewey, bottom right. Top corners, cartouches with the number "1" written in them. Central cartouche shows two human-like figures, flanked on the left by a shipping port and on the right by factory buildings; meant to highlight North Carolina's commercial strengths. Reverse is blank.
mods.accessCondition: Copyright Orange County Historical Museum, Hillsborough, N.C. The images in this collection are made available for use in research, private study, and teaching. Prior permission from the Orange County Historical Museum is required for any commercial use.

titleInfo.title: North Carolina-issued Confederate Currency, Fifty Cents

mods.note: North Carolina-issued Confederate bill for fifty cents. Obverse: central image of a clipper ship at sea. Text written around image reads, "THE STATE OF NORTH CAROLINA/WILL PAY TO/BEARER AT/the Treasury on or before January 1st 1866/FIFTY CENTS." Signed by Thos. Lachorn [sp?]. Image box on right side of obverse shows decorative floral bouquet, on top of which is written, "BY AUTHORITY/of LAW."
mods.accessCondition: Copyright Orange County Historical Museum, Hillsborough, N.C. The images in this collection are made available for use in research, private study, and teaching. Prior permission from the Orange County Historical Museum is required for any commercial use.

titleInfo.title: North Carolina-issued Confederate Currency, Five Cents

mods.note: North Carolina-issued Confederate currency, worth five cents. Bill No. 2145. On obverse, image at center of the bill shows the Great Seal of the State. Text around the seal reads, in part, "THE STATE of NORTH CAROLINA/Wil pay/to Bearer/at the Trea/sury on or before/January/1st 1866/FIVE CENTS." Reverse is blank.

name.namePart: Derrick and Felgemaker Pipe Organ Company.

mods.note: Pipe organ and bench. The pewter pipes are in three rows with the visible pipes decorated with gold leaf and flowers. Made by Derrick and Felgemaker, (which is imprinted above keys), Erie PA, 1831. Used in Hillsborough in the Presbyterian Church. A similar organ by the same builder is in the Cathedral at Notre Dame, South Bend, Indiana. Leslie Derrick, grandchild of Silas Lusher Derrick, the organ maker, has provided information on the family which is in the acquisitions book.

mods.note: The National Register of Historic Places includes the old jail, built in 1839. Henry R. Austin, architect of the original courthouse, also designed the jail with jailers' living quarters on the first floor and the second floor divided into cell blocks. Used as a jail until 1909, Gaston E. Horn then converted the building to a private residence. Hugh S. Larew restored the building in 1970.

The mill organized the band with 20 members in 1917, providing uniforms and instruments. A.A. Hartman served as the first director, followed by Joe Nance, Ernest Fritz, Prof. Shaw, Roberts Mills, and Floyd A. Nail. The band performed for Christmas, 4th of July, picnics, and other amusements in the mill village. Some members later played with other bands, such as Wake Forest College, Clark Brothers Circus, Ringling Brothers Circus, and Sousa.

originInfo.publisher: Davie County Historical and Genealogical Society

mods.note: Peter Hairston purchased the 2,500-acre tract of Cooleemee Plantation in 1817. His great-grandson, Peter Wilson Hairston, expanded the tract to 4,200 acres and constructed the imposing Greek Revival style plantation house from 1853-1855. The house stands 50 feet tall with twelve rooms, a large central hall, and self-supporting wooden staircase. Additional features include woodwork by Philadelphia craftsmen and plasterwork by Italian workmen. The house, listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1973, remains private property of the Hairston family.

During the Civil War, Mrs. Bailey was held at gunpoint by Stonestreet soldiers in the Lee House on Cartner Street when she resisted demands for money; a bed pillow was set on fire, but the soldiers left without harming her. The fire was quickly extinguished, with the only remaining evidence of the incident a charred wallboard on display at the library. The house was built in 1838 by Braxton Bryant Bailey.

mods.note: The Hotel Mocksville opened in 1934. Owned and operated by J. Arthur Daniel, the only hotel in town had 22 rooms. With business strong, Daniel added a third floor in 1935. Traveling salesmen chose to stay at the hotel because of its good food. Chairs lined the sidewalk, allowing guests to enjoy the cooling evening air before retiring to their rooms at night.

mods.note: Erected in 1888 with financing from the Hanes family, the church is largely Gothic Revival. It was listed on the National Register in 1979.

titleInfo.title: State College President Walter N. Ridley and school trustee MacDonald Dixon, circa 1966

mods.note: MacDonald Dixon served on the Board of Trustees from 1957 to 1971. He was a heavy lobbyist for increased state funding for capital improvements and instruction. He supported President Ridley in his efforts to grant bachelor's degrees beyond the Elementary Education major, and successfully presided over a newly-integrated Board.

originInfo.publisher: Davie County Historical and Genealogical Society

mods.note: Local wagonmaker and undertaker John Edward Belle Shutt occupied this house built in about 1885 with a large addition in front in 1905.
mods.accessCondition: This image is presented for research and educational purposes only, and may not be distributed or republished without permission from Davie County Public Library.

mods.note: Charles "Ches" McCartney wandered throughout the country in a wagon pulled by a team of nine goats for close to 40 years (1930-1968). Wearing goatskin clothes, drinking goat's milk, and rarely bathing, the Goat Man preached and told tall tales wherever he went. Muggs Smith recalls seeing the Goat Man in Mocksville during the 1950s.
mods.accessCondition: This image is presented for research and educational purposes only, and may not be distributed or republished without permission from Davie County Public Library.

mods.note: Mocksville native Mariah Elizabeth Nail stood only 36 inches tall and weighed 48 pounds. She traveled throughout the United States and Europe with the circus as one of the world's smallest women. She met her diminutive husband, Major John Mertz, "Major Mite" while touring. The couple traveled with the Barnum Circus, Adam Forepaugh, and John Robinson Shows. They retired from the circus in 1911 and lived in Salisbury until their deaths.
mods.accessCondition: This image is presented for research and educational purposes only, and may not be distributed or republished without permission from Davie County Public Library.

mods.note: Erwin Mills Company established the town of Cooleemee, building the cotton mill on the South Yadkin River in 1899. In peak operation, the mill employed 1,800 workers. Until closing in 1969, the mill sponsored a broad range of recreational, social, religious, civic, and educational opportunities.
mods.accessCondition: This image is presented for research and educational purposes only, and may not be distributed or republished without permission from Davie County Public Library.

originInfo.publisher: Davie County Historical and Genealogical Society

mods.note: Jesse A. Clement built the plantation house around 1828 making it one of the oldest homes in the county. Rev. William F. Long, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church in Mocksville from 1958 to 1962, purchased the home in 1978 from the Clement heirs and restored it to its original condition. The National Park Service listed the house on the National Register of Historic Places in 1979.
mods.accessCondition: This image is presented for research and educational purposes only, and may not be distributed or republished without permission from Davie County Public Library.

originInfo.publisher: Davie County Historical and Genealogical Society

mods.note: Built in 1892 for $250, the church features an L-shaped frame with the altar positioned at the intersection of the wings. The congregation met here until 1961 when a new brick church was completed. The picturesque church is one of few unaltered chapels in the county. Zion traces its roots to brush arbor meetings between 1758 and 1763, believed to have been held on the Daniel Ratledge grant land adjacent to the Georgia Road.
mods.accessCondition: This image is presented for research and educational purposes only, and may not be distributed or republished without permission from Davie County Public Library.

mods.note: The old courthouse became the Davie County Community Building in 1915.
mods.accessCondition: This image is presented for research and educational purposes only, and may not be distributed or republished without permission from Davie County Public Library.

mods.note: Named for the settlement known as Mocks Old Field, Mocksville incorporated in 1839. Civic leaders erected the courthouse in the center of the one and one half acres set aside as a public square and business district. The business center of town shifted to the downtown square from present-day Salisbury Street. Town limits radiated one half mile in every direction from the new courthouse.
mods.accessCondition: This image is presented for research and educational purposes only, and may not be distributed or republished without permission from Davie County Public Library.

mods.note: Built by Dr. James McGuire in the 1880s, the Philip Hanes family rented the house in 1901 before A. Turner Grant's purchase in 1910. The now-demolished structure stood on the site of the First Baptist church's current parking lot.
mods.accessCondition: This image is presented for research and educational purposes only, and may not be distributed or republished without permission from Davie County Public Library.

titleInfo.title: North Carolina-issued Confederate Currency, Three Dollars

mods.note: North Carolina-issued Confederate currency. Three dollars, No. 1408. Obverse text reads, in part "THE STATE of NORTH CAROLINA/Will pay THREE DOLLARS to Bearer/Redeemable at the TREASURY on or before the/FIRST DAY OF JANUARY 1866." Cartouche at center shows classical scene: two woman, one standing and one seated, at the foot of a fluted column; cornucopia beside the seated figure. Signed by C. D. Dewey. "THREE" written vertical along both sides of the bill. Reverse is blank.
